title: Fully-homomorphic encryption, zero-knowledge proofs, and multiparty computation

submitter_user.about:
I am a developer that loves building distributed systems, especially with open source technologies. My blog is called [Not a Monad Tutorial](http://notamonadtutorial.com/). I am the tech lead of a small company I own called [LambdaClass](https://github.com/lambdaclass/).

The language I like the most for that task is Erlang since it has a lot of built-in tools and features that other languages don't have. In companion with Erlang, I usually use databases such as Cassandra, Riak, Elasticsearch, Redis, PostgreSQL and message queues such as Kafka or RabbitMQ. I work a lot with FreeBSD, OpenBSD, Linux and devops tools like Ansible, Chef, Terraform, Grafana and Prometheus. The last year I've started doing some work in the Deep Learning space with Python, Keras, PyTorch and TensorFlow.

At last I love playing with OCaml, Racket/Lisp, Rust and Elm.
I am a programmer who likes playing music...
I am a programmer who likes playing music...

title: What more recent developments in PLT could be useful in languages targeting much older/limited hardw
description:
We see on occasion some rather interesting features come along in PLT such as ocaml‚Äôs effects, and various haskell related things.

I am also interested in the Commander X16 computer that is being developed using a 6502, similar to a C64 for comparison.

So I was wondering what would be features either seen in more modern languages or more theoretical PLT research could be of benefit to languages targeting machines that have limited resources such as 8 bit cpu, 64kB ram, etc?
description_plain:
We see on occasion some rather interesting features come along in PLT such as ocaml's effects, and various haskell related things.

I am also interested in the Commander X16 computer that is being developed using a 6502, similar to a C64 for comparison.

So I was wondering what would be features either seen in more modern languages or more theoretical PLT research could be of benefit to languages targeting machines that have limited resources such as 8 bit cpu, 64kB ram, etc?

title: SantaCoder - a 1.1B multilingual LM for code
description:
[Source: https://twitter.com/BigCodeProject/status/1605958778330849281]

Announcing a holiday gift: üéÖSantaCoder - a 1.1B multilingual LM for code that outperforms much larger open-source models on both left-to-right generation and infilling!

Paper: https://hf.co/datasets/bigcode/admin/resolve/main/BigCode_SantaCoder.pdf
